questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with a painful wound infection following an injury sustained while handling seafood. Upon evaluation, a Gram-negative, salt-tolerant bacterium is identified. Which of the following organisms is not classified as a non-fermenting bacterium?
questions.solution:
Vibrio alginolyticus is a fermenting Gram-negative bacterium. It is capable of fermenting carbohydrates, particularly in saline environments, and is commonly associated with seafood and marine environments.

 

Non-Fermenting Bacteria

  • Metabolism:
    • Primarily oxidative metabolism, as these organisms do not ferment sugars.
  • Examples:
    • Pseudomonas (Option A ruled out)
    • Burkholderia pseudomallei (Option C ruled out)
    • Burkholderia mallei
    • Acinetobacter baumannii (Option B ruled out)
    • Vibrio parahaemolyticus:
      • Shows kanagawa phenomenon on wagatsuma agar.
      • on microscopy shows Bipolar safety pin appearance

Organisms showing bipolar safety pin appearance on microscopy:

  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei( causing melioidosis)
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Vibrio alginolyticus

  • Characteristics:
    • Halophilic (salt-loving)
    • Capable of fermenting sucrose (Option D)
  • Clinical Associations:
    • Linked to infections of the eyes, ears, and wounds in humans exposed to seawater.

questions.text: A patient with watery diarrhea tests positive for Vibrio cholerae O1. Which of the following laboratory findings is useful in differentiating the El Tor biotype from the classical biotype of Vibrio cholerae?

choices.text: The classical biotype is resistant to polymyxin B.
El Tor biotype shows negative chick erythrocyte agglutination..
The classical biotype does not cause hemolysis of sheep RBCs.
El Tor biotype is susceptible to group IV phage

questions.solution:
The El Tor biotype of Vibrio cholerae O1 shows hemolysis of sheep red blood cells (RBCs), while the classical biotype does not. Hemolysis of sheep RBCs is one of the distinguishing features of the El Tor biotype, which helps differentiate it from the classical biotype in the laboratory.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with severe, watery diarrhea resembling "rice-water stools" and signs of dehydration. Laboratory tests confirm a Vibrio cholerae infection. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which cholera toxin induces watery diarrhea?

choices.text: Causes direct intestinal mucosal damage, leading to inflammation and diarrhea
Activates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased cyclic AMP levels
Increases cyclic GMP levels in intestinal cells
B subunit binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal cells

questions.solution:
Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection. (Option A ruled out)

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea. (Option B)
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Increases cyclic GMP levels in intestinal cells (Option C) Heat-stable toxin (ST) of E.coli increases intracellular cGMP levels causing watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with severe, watery diarrhea and dehydration after consuming food while traveling in a region known for cholera outbreaks. He is initiated on oral rehydration solution (ORS). Which of the following diagnostic tests is the most specific for confirming an infection with Vibrio cholerae in this patient?

choices.text: Stool culture on thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar

questions.solution:
TCBS agar is a selective culture medium specifically designed for isolating Vibrio species, including Vibrio cholerae. It allows for the growth of alkaline-tolerant bacteria and inhibits the growth of most other enteric bacteria. Colonies of Vibrio cholerae typically appear as yellow on this medium due to sucrose fermentation, making this method highly specific for confirming the diagnosis.

Diagnosis of Vibrio cholerae

Specimen Collection:

  • Preferred Specimen: Stool (mucus flakes)
  • Alternative: Rectal swab if stool is not available
  • Enrichment broth : selenite F broth and alkaline peptone water

Transport Media:

  • VR (Venkatraman Ramakrishnan) media - specific transport media for V. cholera (Option D ruled out)
  • Cary-Blair medium

Microscopy:

  • Morphology: Comma or curved-shaped, reddish Gram-negative bacilli.
  • Appearance: Fish-in-stream appearance
  • Motility: Demonstrated by dark field or phase contrast microscopy showing darting motility.

Culture:

  • Culture Media and Colony Characteristics:
    • MacConkey Agar: Colorless colonies that may later turn pink due to late fermentation of lactose
    • Blood Agar: Green colonies indicating hemolysis
    • Nutrient Agar: Translucent, round discs with a bluish tinge under transmitted light
    • Gelatin Stab: Infundibuliform (funnel-shaped) or napiform (turnip-shaped) liquefaction

Selective Media:

  • Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose (TCBS) Agar: (Option A)
    • Differentiates between sucrose fermenters (like Vibrio cholerae) and non-sucrose fermenters (such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus).
    • Vibrio cholerae produces yellow colonies due to sucrose fermentation.


Biochemical Reactions:

  • Fermentation: Glucose and sucrose
  • Indole Test: Positive
  • Nitrate Reduction: Nitrates are reduced to nitrites
  • Cholera Red Reaction: Due to nitroso-indole formation
  • Catalase: Positive
  • Oxidase: Positive
  • String Test:
    • A loopful of growth mixed with 0.5% deoxycholate results in string formation

Serological Tests (Not useful for diagnosis)

  • Indirect Hemagglutination
  • Complement-Dependent Vibriocidal Antibody Test (Option B ruled out)

Treatment:

  • Rehydration:
    • Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)
    • Intravenous (IV) fluids
  • Antibiotics: Secondary treatment


Susceptibility to Cholera Phage IV (Option C): Susceptibility to Cholera Phage IV differentiates between classical cholera and El Tor vibrios.

questions.text: Which virulence factor of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is known to inhibit protein synthesis in host cells?
questions.solution:
Exotoxin A is a potent virulence factor of Pseudomonas aeruginosa that inhibits protein synthesis in host cells. It does this by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is crucial for the translation process during protein synthesis. By interfering with this process, Exotoxin A leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenicity of the bacterium.

Pseudomonas Pigments: Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces several pigments that diffuse freely into their surroundings, inhibiting other bacteria and mediating tissue injury:

  • Pyocyanin: Blue-green color
  • Pyoverdine: Yellow-green color, fluorescent
  • Pyorubin: Red-brown color
  • Pyomelanin: Brown-black color

Virulence Factors: Pseudomonas aeruginosa has multiple virulence factors that contribute to its pathogenicity:

  • Exotoxin A:
    • Inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor-2, leading to cell death.
  • Elastases (LasA and LasB):
    • Degrade elastin, collagen, and other host tissues, facilitating spread and invasion.
  • Alkaline Protease:
    • Degrades host proteins, aiding in tissue invasion and immune evasion.
  • Phospholipase C:
    • Degrades phospholipids in host cell membranes, contributing to cell lysis and tissue damage.
  • Type III Secretion System (T3SS):
    • Injects toxins directly into host cells, disrupting cellular processes and evading immune responses.
  • Biofilm Formation:
    • Protects bacteria from antibiotics and host immune responses, promoting chronic infection and persistence.
  • Non-Diffusible Toxins:
    • Exotoxins S, U, T, and Y allow the bacteria to evade phagocytic cells and induce tissue injuries.

Clinical Features: Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause a variety of infections, with the following clinical features based on infection type and affected populations:

Infection Type

Affected Population

Symptoms and Clinical Features

Pulmonary Infections

Cystic fibrosis patients, individuals with chronic lung diseases

Persistent cough, sputum production, shortness of breath, fever, chest pain, difficulty breathing

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)

Catheterized patients, individuals with anatomical abnormalities

Dysuria, frequency, urgency, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, lower abdominal pain

Skin and Soft Tissue Infections

Burn patients, individuals with wounds

Redness, swelling, pus formation, pain, delayed wound healing

Bacteremia and Septicemia

Immunocompromised patients

Fever, chills, hypotension, multi-organ failure, altered mental status

Otitis Externa (Swimmer's Ear)

Swimmers, individuals with ear injuries

Ear pain, itching, discharge, hearing loss, redness, swelling of the outer ear

Endocarditis

Intravenous drug users, individuals with prosthetic heart valves

Fever, heart murmur, fatigue, chest pain, signs of heart failure

Gastrointestinal Infections

Immunocompromised individuals, children

Diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting

Keratitis and Conjunctivitis

Contact lens wearers, individuals with eye trauma

Eye pain, redness, discharge, blurred vision, potential vision loss

Other features associated with P.aeruginosa:

  • Hot tub folliculitis
  • Shanghai fever
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Elastase (Option A):

  • Elastase is a proteolytic enzyme produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa that breaks down elastin and other proteins in host tissues.
  • While it contributes to tissue damage and inflammation, it does not directly inhibit protein synthesis in host cells.

Phospholipase C (Option C):

  • Phospholipase C is an enzyme that hydrolyzes phospholipids, leading to the production of lysophospholipids and fatty acids.
  • While it can contribute to tissue damage and inflammatory responses, it does not inhibit protein synthesis in host cells.

 

Biofilm (Option D):

  • Biofilm formation is a survival strategy that allows Pseudomonas aeruginosa to adhere to surfaces and resist host immune responses and antibiotic treatment.
  • Although biofilms enhance the virulence of the bacteria by providing a protective environment, they do not directly inhibit protein synthesis in host cells.

questions.text: Which biochemical test is most frequently employed to confirm the presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by detecting an enzyme characteristic of this organism?
questions.solution:
The oxidase test is used to detect the presence of cytochrome c oxidase, an enzyme that is a key characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This organism is oxidase-positive, making this test a reliable method for confirming its identification.

Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics.

 

Indole test (Option A): This test is used to identify bacteria that can produce indole from tryptophan, but it is not typically used for identifying Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Urease test (Option B): This test detects the presence of urease enzyme, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is typically urease negative.

Coagulase test (Option D): This test is used to identify Staphylococcus aureus based on the production of coagulase enzyme and is not relevant for Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A patient presents with pneumonia and septicemia after returning from a tropical region. Which organism is most likely responsible, and which specialized culture medium should be used for its isolation?

choices.text: Salmonella typhi - Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar

questions.solution:
Burkholderia pseudomallei is the causative agent of melioidosis, which can present with pneumonia and septicemia, particularly in individuals returning from tropical regions, especially Southeast Asia. Ashdown's medium is a selective culture medium used specifically for isolating B. pseudomallei from clinical specimens. It inhibits the growth of contaminating flora while promoting the growth of this organism.

Salmonella typhi (Option B): Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar: Salmonella typhi, causing typhoid fever, is typically isolated on XLD agar, which inhibits the growth of Gram-positive organisms and aids in the differentiation of Salmonella species.

 

Leptospira interrogans (Option C): EMJH medium: Leptospira interrogans, causing leptospirosis, is best cultured in EMJH (Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris) medium under specific conditions suitable for the growth of spirochetes.


Moraxella catarrhalis (Option D): Chocolate agar: Moraxella catarrhalis, causing respiratory infections, is cultured on chocolate agar, which provides enriched growth conditions.
